utterances: When you look ahead for the next two to three years, do you see this money reappearing for non-profits specifically?
Do you think people will find ways of replacing the funds?
Or do you think there's going to be a rough road for non-profits?
Well, if they're looking for the money to come back from the Madoff scandal, the answer is no. You know, Madoff had spent a lot of that money, and a lot of that money will never be recovered.

For non-profits in general, I think the bigger threat to non-profits is the economic downturn, and the fact that a lot of charitable giving has declined substantially as a result of the economic struggles that we're having as a country right now.

I do believe optimistically that, within the year, the bulk of the recession will be over, and we can get back to business as usual, while at the same time, there are some serious long term problems in the economy which may not even reveal themselves for another three of four years.
It sounds like - are there any potential sources that you can see that might replace some of the lost moneys?
Well, you know, I can't really say for sure.
I don't really think that the model for non-profit giving is going to change very much.
I think that it's sort of like the weather, you know, when it's raining you just come inside or you get an umbrella and you wait the storm out.
And I think that - I know that here in Syracuse, for example, we found that a lot of our giving had declined as the result of the economy.
Some of our investment strategy changed.
Where we managed our money, how we allocated our funds changed.
We tightened our belt a little bit.
And the hope is that you wait it out, and things will eventually get better.
I don't think that the model for giving is going to change very much.

There is certainly a lot more to get out here, and there are a lot of reasons for that, but the primary reason is we've suffered from a convict at all cost mentality.

Well, we're certainly asking them, expecting much from the State of Texas is a tricky proposition, especially when it comes down to criminal justice reform, although there are a lot of encouraging signs with this legislature, and I think that, frankly, a lot of legislators have now decided that there really is a crisis in this state with a number of folks that we've been able to get out and that the Innocence Project nationally has been able to get out here.
So we're hopeful that they're going to have some impetus to really step up and do the right thing.
Finally, when you think about your options, you mentioned you're not in good shape, you're looking to the state.
If the state doesn't ante up, could you close?
It's conceivable.

Under the current set up that we've got, like, let's just say, things remained absolutely the same, that there was no increase from the state, we would be able to operate a small clinical program out of one law school.
But its ability to get much done would be pretty severely hampered.

The key to us, because it's such a huge state and there are so many cases, and we have a gigantic prison system, is being able to mobilize lawyers and volunteers and law students from all over the state, instead of just one little town or one little region.
So it's critical for us, to really do our job right, to be able to get more money.
